name: mitchella-repens
wildlife-value: Its fruits are eaten by songbirds, ruffed grouse, wild turkeys, quail, and small mammals.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: This plant is moderately resistant to damage from deer.
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: The flowers are subsequently followed by round, bright red  berries that typically ripen in late summer (June-July) . A pair of flowers yields one berry, hence the additional common name of twinberry for this plant. The berries, which have a tiny dimple and star-shaped marks, are edible but rather tasteless. The berries often persist on the plants throughout winter. They are 1/4" long and 3/8" across.
flower-description: 1/2" long bloom in spring in pairs with a single calyx mostly at the stem ends. Fragrant, four-lobed, funnel tubular shape, hairy white petals which are lightly flushed with pink.
leaf-description: Partridgeberry has oval to heart-shaped, opposite, glossy, dark green leaves (to 3/4â€ long, 1/2" wide) with whitish veins appear in pairs along the stems pale yellow midrib and below.
stem-description: Twigs are very delicate and barely woody. They are pale green to brown in color.  The stems root at nodes where they touch the ground.
